title: 109_hr6116
content: The Act may be cited as the "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" and focuses on enhancing Border Patrol agents. The "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" aims to address recruitment and retention challenges faced by the United States Border Patrol. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a plan within six months to improve recruitment and retention of well-qualified Border Patrol agents. The plan includes strategies for recruitment and retention authorities to ensure agents have appropriate skills and training. The "More Border Patrol Agents Now Act of 2006" requires an assessment of current pay levels for Border Patrol agents and the impact on recruitment and retention, especially in high cost-of-living areas. It also calls for an evaluation of increased flexibility in transferring agents between duty stations to improve morale and recruitment efforts. SEC. 3. Recruitment and retention bonuses for Border Patrol agents enhancement. Sec. 9702 of title 5, United States Code, allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to pay recruitment bonuses to individuals to recruit Border Patrol agents, not exceeding 25% of the annual rate of basic pay. The bonus is a lump-sum payment and is not considered part of basic pay. Payment of a bonus under this section is contingent upon entering into a written service agreement with the United States Border Patrol, specifying the service period and conditions for termination. The bonus cannot be paid to recruit individuals for certain high-level positions. The authority to pay bonuses under this section will terminate five years after enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay retention bonuses to Border Patrol agents who enter into a service agreement to complete a specified period of service. The Secretary of Homeland Security may pay retention bonuses to Border Patrol agents, not exceeding 25% of annual basic pay, in a lump-sum payment. Bonuses cannot be based on the same service period as recruitment bonuses and the authority expires five years after enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security can appoint annuitants to positions within the United States Border Patrol to address challenges. An annuitant in this position is not subject to certain provisions and is not considered an employee for retirement purposes. The authority to make appointments will expire five years after enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security can appoint annuitants to positions within the United States Border Patrol to address challenges. An annuitant in this position is not subject to certain provisions and is not considered an employee for retirement purposes. The authority to make appointments will expire after ten years from the date of enactment. Border Patrol agent enhancement allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to appoint annuitants to address challenges, with exemptions from certain provisions and retirement status. The authority to make appointments will expire after ten years.
